FRIEND.</br>You say, "it hurts you to the soul</br>To brook confinement or controul."</br>And yet will voluntary run</br>To that confinement you would shun,</br>Content to drudge along the track,</br>With bells and harness on your back.</br>Alas!  what genius can admit</br>A monthly tax on spendthrift wit,</br>Which often flings whole stores away,</br>And oft has not a doit to pay!</br>—Give us a work, indeed — of length—</br>Something which speaks poetic strength;</br>Is sluggish fancy at a stand?</br>No scheme of consequence in hand?</br>I, nor your plan, nor book condemn,</br>But why your name, and why A M?

AUTHOR.</br>Yes — it stands forth to public view,</br>Within, without, on white, on blue,</br>In proper, tall, gigantic Letters,</br>Not dash'd — emvowell'd — like my betters.</br>And though it stares me in the face,</br>Reflects no shame, hints no disgrace.</br>While these unlaboured trifles please,</br>Familiar chains are worn with ease.</br>—Behold!  to yours and my surprize,</br>These trifles to a VOLUME rise.</br>Thus will you see me, as I go,</br>Still gath'ring bulk like balls of snow,</br>Steal by degrees upon your shelf,</br>And grow a giant from an elf.</br>The current studies of the day,</br>Can rarely reach beyond a PLAY:</br>A PAMPHLET may deserve a look,</br>But Heav'n defend us from a BOOK!</br>A LIBEL flies on Scandal's wings,</br>But works of length are heavy things.</br>—Not one in twenty will succeed—</br>Consider, sir, how few can read.
FRIEND.</br>I mean a work of merit—
AUTHOR.</br>True.
FRIEND.</br>A man of Taste MUST buy.
AUTHOR.</br>Yes; — You;</br>And half a dozen more, my friend,</br>Whom your good Taste shall recommend.</br>Experience will by facts prevail,</br>When argument and reason fail;</br>The NUPTIALS now—
FRIEND.</br>Whose nuptials, sir?—

AUTHOR.</br>A Poet's — did that poem stir?</br>No — fixt — tho' thousand readers pass,</br>It still looks through its pane of glass,</br>And seems indignant to exclaim</br>Pass on ye SONS of TASTE, for shame!

While duly each revolving moon,</br>Which often comes, God knows, too soon,</br>Continual plagues my soul molest,</br>And Magazines disturb my rest,</br>While scarce a night I steal to bed,</br>Without a couplet in my head,</br>And in the morning, when I stir,</br>Pop comes a Devil, "Copy sir."</br>I cannot strive with daring flight</br>To reach the bold Parnassian HEIGHT;</br>But at its foot, content to stray,</br>In easy unambitious way,</br>Pick up those flowers the muses send,</br>To make a nosegay for my friend.</br>In short, I lay no idle claim</br>To genius strong, and noisy fame.</br>But with a hope and wish to please,</br>I write, as I would live, with ease.
FRIEND.</br>But you must have a fund, a mine,</br>Prose, poems, letters

AUTHOR.</br>Not a line.</br>And here, my friend, I rest secure;</br>He can't lose much, who's always poor.</br>And if, as now, thro' numbers five,</br>This work with pleasure kept alive,</br>Can still its currency afford,</br>Nor fear the breaking of its hoard,</br>Can pay you, as at sundry times,</br>For self per Mag, two thousand Rhimes,</br>From whence should apprehension grow,</br>That self should fail, with richer Co?

No doer of a monthly grub,</br>Myself alone a learned club,</br>I ask my readers to no treat</br>Of scientifick hash'd-up meat,</br>Nor seek to please theatric friends</br>With scraps of plays, and odds and ends.—
FRIEND.</br>Your method, sir, is plain enough;</br>And all the world has read your PUFF.</br>Th' allusion's neat, expression clean,</br>About your travelling MACHINE,</br>But yet — it is a Magazine.

AUTHOR.</br>Why let it be, and wherefore shame?</br>As JULIET says, what's in a name?</br>Besides it is the way of trade,</br>Through which all science is convey'd,</br>Thus knowledge parcels out her shares;</br>The COURT has hers, the LAWYERS theirs.</br>Something to SCHOLARS sure is due,—</br>Why not one MAGAZINE for YOU?

FRIEND.</br>That's an Herculean task, my friend,</br>You toil and labour — to offend.</br>Part of your scheme — a free translation,</br>To SCHOLARS is a profanation;</br>What!  break up Latin!  pull down Greek!</br>(Peace to the soul of sir JOHN CHEEKE!</br>And shall the gen'rous liquor run,</br>Broach'd from the rich FALERNIAN tun?</br>Will you pour out to English swine,</br>Neat as imported, old GREEK wine?</br>Alas!  such beverage only fits</br>Collegiate tastes, and classic wits.

AUTHOR.</br>I seek not, with satyric stroke,</br>To strip the pedant of his cloak;</br>No — let him cull and spout quotations,</br>And call the jabber, demonstrations;</br>Be his the great concern to shew,</br>If Roman gowns were tied or no;</br>Whether the Grecians took a slice</br>Four times a-day, or only twice,</br>Still let him work about his hole,</br>Poor, busy, blind, laborious mole;</br>Still let him puzzle, read, explain,</br>Oppugn, remark, and read again.
Such, though they waste the midnight oil</br>In dull, minute, perplexing toil,</br>Not understanding, do no good,</br>Nor can do harm, not understood.

By scholars, apprehend me right,</br>I mean the learned, and polite,</br>Whose knowledge unaffected flows,</br>And sits as easy as their cloaths;</br>Who care not though an "ac" or "sed"</br>Misplac'd, endanger PRISCIAN'S head;</br>Nor think his wit a grain the worse,</br>Who cannot frame a Latin verse,</br>Or give the Roman PROPER word</br>To things the ROMANS never heard.

'Tis true, except among the Great,</br>Letters are rather out of date,</br>And quacking genius more discerning,</br>Scoffs at your regulars in learning.</br>—PEDANTS, indeed, are learning's curse,</br>But IGNORANCE is something worse:</br>All are not blest with reputation,</br>Built on the WANT of EDUCATION,</br>And some, to letters duly bred,</br>Mayn't write the worse, because they've read.</br>Though books had better be unknown,</br>Than not one thought appear our own;</br>As some can never speak themselves,</br>But through the authors on their shelves,</br>Whose writing smacks too much of reading,</br>As affectation spoils good breeding.

FRIEND.</br>True; but that fault is seldom known,</br>Save in your bookish college drone,</br>Who, constant (as I've heard them say)</br>Study their fourteen hours a-day,</br>And squatting close, with dull attention,</br>Read themselves out of apprehension;</br>Who scarce can wash their hands or face,</br>For fear of losing time, or place,</br>And give one hour to meat and drink,</br>But never half a one to THINK.

AUTHOR.</br>Lord!  I have seen a thousand such,</br>Who read, or seem to read, too much.</br>So have I known, in that rare place,</br>Where Classics always breed disgrace,</br>A wight, upon discoveries hot,</br>As whether flames have heat or not,</br>Study himself, poor sceptic dunce,</br>Into the very fire at once,</br>And clear the philosophic doubt,</br>By burning all ideas out.</br>With such, eternal books successive</br>Lead to no sciences progressive,</br>While each dull fit of study past,</br>Just like a wedge drives out the last.

From these I ground no expectation</br>Of genuine wit, or free translation;</br>But you mistake me, friend.  Suppose,</br>(Translations are but modern cloaths)</br>I dress my boy — (for instance sake</br>Maintain these children, which I make)</br>I give him coat and breeches—
FRIEND.</br>True—</br>But not a bib and apron too!</br>You would not let your child be seen,</br>But drest consistent, neat, and clean.

AUTHOR.</br>So would I cloath a free translation,</br>Or as POPE calls it, imitation;</br>Not pull down authors from my shelf,</br>To spoil their wit, and plague myself,</br>My learning studious to display,</br>And lose their spirit by the way.

FRIEND.</br>Your HORACE now — e'en borrow thence</br>His easy wit, his manly sense,</br>But let the Moralist convey</br>Things in the manners of to-day,</br>Rather than that old garb assume,</br>Which only suits a man at Rome.

AUTHOR.</br>Originals will always please,</br>And copies too, if done with ease.</br>Would not old PLAUTUS wish to wear,</br>Turn'd English host, an English air,</br>If THORNTON, rich in native wit,</br>Would make the modes and diction fit?</br>Or, as I know you hate to roam,</br>To fetch an instance nearer home;</br>Though in an idiom most unlike,</br>A similarity must strike,</br>Where both of simple nature fond,</br>In art and genius correspond;</br>And naive both (allow the phrase</br>Which no one English word conveys)</br>Wrapt up their stories neat and clean,</br>Easy as—
</br>FRIEND.</br>DENIS'S you mean.</br>—The very man — not mere translation,</br>But LA FONTAINE by transmigration.

AUTHOR.</br>Authors, as DRYDEN'S maxim runs,</br>Have what he calls poetic sons.</br>Thus MILTON, more correctly wild,</br>Was richer SPENSER'S lawful child.</br>And CHURCHILL, got on all the nine,</br>Is DRYDEN'S heir in ev'ry line.</br>Thus DENIS proves his parents plain,</br>The child of EASE, and LA FONTAINE.
FRIEND.</br>His muse, indeed, the work secures,</br>And asks our praise as much as yours;</br>For, if delighted, readers too</br>May pay their thanks, as well as you.

But YOU, my friend (so folks complain)</br>For ever in this easy vein,</br>This prose in verse, this measur'd talk,</br>This pace, that's neither trot nor walk,</br>Aim at no flights, nor strive to give</br>A real poem fit to live.

AUTHOR.</br>(To critics no offence, I hope)</br>PRIOR shall live as long as POPE,</br>Each in his manner sure to please,</br>While both have strength, and both have ease;</br>Yet though their various beauties strike,</br>Their ease, their strength is not alike.</br>Both with consummate horseman's skill,</br>Ride as they list, about the hill;</br>But take, peculiar in their mode,</br>Their favourite horse, and favourite road.

For me, once fond of author-fame,</br>Now forc'd to bear its weight and shame,</br>I have no time to run a race,</br>A traveller's my only pace.</br>They, whom their steeds unjaded bear</br>Around Hyde-park, to take the air,</br>May frisk and prance, and ride their fill,</br>And go all paces which they will;</br>We, hackney tits — nay, never smile,</br>Who trot our stage of thirty mile,</br>Must travel in a constant plan,</br>And run our journey, as we can.

FRIEND.</br>A critic says, upon whose sleeve</br>Some pin more faith than you'll believe,</br>That writings which as easy please,</br>Are not the writings wrote with ease.</br>From whence the inference is plain,</br>Your friend MAT PRIOR wrote with pain.

AUTHOR.</br>With pain perhaps he might correct,</br>With care supply each loose defect,</br>Yet sure, if rhime, which seems to flow,</br>Whether its master will or no,</br>If humour, not by study sought,</br>But rising from immediate thought,</br>Are proofs of ease, what hardy name</br>Shall e'er dispute a PRIOR'S claim!

But still your critic's observation</br>Strikes at no POET'S reputation,</br>His keen reflection only hits</br>Your rhiming fops, and pedling wits.</br>As some take stiffness for a grace,</br>And walk a dancing-master's pace,</br>And others, for familiar air</br>Mistake the slouching of a bear;</br>So some will finically trim,</br>And dress their lady-muse too prim,</br>Others, mere slovens in their pen</br>(The mob of Lords and Gentlemen)</br>Fancy they write with ease and pleasure,</br>By rambling out of rhime and measure.</br>And, on your critic's judgment, these</br>Write easily, and not with EASE.

There are, indeed, whose wish pursues,</br>And inclination courts the muse;</br>Who, happy in a partial fame,</br>A while possess a poet's name,</br>But read their works, examine fair,</br>—Shew me invention, fancy there,</br>Taste I allow; but is the flow</br>Of genius in them?  Surely, no.</br>'Tis labour from the classic brain.</br>Read your own ADDISON'S CAMPAIGN.

E'en he, nay, think me not severe,</br>A critic fine, of Latin ear,</br>Who toss'd his classic thoughts around</br>With elegance on Roman ground,</br>Just simmering with the muse's flame</br>Woos but a cool and sober dame;</br>And all his English rhimes express</br>But beggar-thoughts in royal dress.</br>In verse his genius seldom glows,</br>A POET only in his prose,</br>Which rolls luxuriant, rich, and chaste,</br>Improved by Fancy, Wit, and Taste.

FRIEND.</br>I task you for yourself, my friend,</br>A subject you can ne'er defend,</br>And you cajole me all the while</br>With dissertations upon stile.</br>Leave others wits and works alone,</br>And think a little of your own,</br>For FAME, when all is said and done,</br>Tho' a coy mistress, may be won;</br>And half the thought, and pains, and time,</br>You take to jingle easy rhime,</br>Would make an ODE, would make a PLAY,</br>Done into English, MALLOCH'S way,</br>—Stretch out your more Heroic feet,</br>And write an ELEGY complete.</br>Or, not a more laborious task,</br>Could not you pen a Classic MASQUE?

AUTHOR.</br>With will at large, and unclogg'd wings,</br>I durst not soar to such high things.</br>For I, who have more phlegm than fire,</br>Must understand, or not admire,</br>But when I read with admiration,</br>Perhaps I'll write in IMITATION.
FRIEND.</br>But business of this monthly kind,</br>Need that alone engross your mind.</br>Assistance must pour in a-pace,</br>New passengers will take a place,</br>And then your friends—
AUTHOR.</br>Aye, they indeed,</br>Might make a better work succeed,</br>And with the helps which they shall give,</br>I and the Magazine shall live.
FRIEND.</br>Yes, live, and eat, and nothing more.
AUTHOR.</br>I'll live as — Authors did before.</br>
